title: "The Book Of The Damned" condensed display sans from 60s book cover
content:
![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080828001205im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/bookofdamnedcrop_6487.jpg)

I love that K!

Anyone have any idea what this might be?

 [‹ Geoffrey Bradfield "Millennium Modern" book cover type](http://web.archive.org/web/20080828001205/http:/www.typophile.com/node/36756 "Go to previous forum topic") [(x) "54" classic serif face - Adobe Garamond {Randall Laurence Smith} ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080828001205/http:/www.typophile.com/node/36838 "Go to next forum topic")
author: toog

comments.content: Not quite that one, but the K is similar : [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/chank/nicotine/](http://web.archive.org/web/20080828001205/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/chank/nicotine/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/chank/nicotine/")

Hmmm, I don’t really know.

It was first published in 1919 but this is an obvious reissue sometime later.

Here’s the full cover:  
 [http://manybooks.net/original\_covers/f/fortc/fortc2247222472-8.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20080828001205/http:/manybooks.net/original_covers/f/fortc/fortc2247222472-8.jpg "http://manybooks.net/original\_covers/f/fortc/fortc2247222472-8.jpg")

The logo in the upper left feels sixties to me but I could be dumb.
I hope that means we’re getting closer...I really like this one.

It might be an old Ludlow face “Gothic Condensed” or Extra Condensed.

ChrisL

Funny you see it as <cite>Czech influenced</cite>, Chris.  
In this German [Fontblog thread](http://web.archive.org/web/20080828001205/http:/www.fontblog.de/helvetica-der-kulturen-der-welt) (about the recently replaced logo of [Haus der Kulturen der Welt](http://web.archive.org/web/20080828001205/http:/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haus_der_Kulturen_der_Welt), designed by [Cornel Windlin](http://web.archive.org/web/20080828001205/http:/www.typophile.com/wiki/Cornel%252BWindlin)/ [Neville Brody](http://web.archive.org/web/20080828001205/http:/www.typophile.com/wiki/Neville%252BBrody)), [HD Schellnack](http://web.archive.org/web/20080828001205/http:/www.fontblog.de/helvetica-der-kulturen-der-welt#comment-28235) characterizes a similar ‘K’ with ‘bent leg’ as having a ‘Russian touch’.

I would grant that the Czechs had a very strong Russian influence, particulary during the era of the Soviet Union. I think the Czechs were far more likely to be open to experimentation in letterforms and gutsy about implementing them. Veronika Burian gave an inspiring presentation at TypeCon ’07 showing some very innovative examples of Czech work.

[http://flickr.com/photos/ebensorkin/1225352194/in/photostream/](http://web.archive.org/web/20080828001205/http:/flickr.com/photos/ebensorkin/1225352194/in/photostream/ "http://flickr.com/photos/ebensorkin/1225352194/in/photostream/")

ChrisL
